questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Unilateral thinning of optic nerve

Explanation:

Option A is correct because eye pain with eye movement is a common symptom of optic neuritis in NMOSD. Option B is also correct, as longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM) is a hallmark of NMOSD, involving ≥3 vertebral segments. Option D is true since afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) occurs due to optic nerve involvement. Option C is incorrect because NMOSD usually causes bilateral  optic neuritis, unlike MS which more often presents with unilateral involvement and has inflamamtion and thickened appearance on MRI orbits. Hence, this is the correct answer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with asymmetric muscle weakness in the arms and legs. Nerve conduction studies reveal focal demyelination with conduction block. Anti GM1 antibody is present. Which of the following conditions is most likely indicated by these findings?

choices.text: Multifocal Motor Neuropathy with Conduction Block

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Multifocal Motor Neuropathy with Conduction Block (MMN)

 

Explanation:

Features that support diagnosis of Multifocal motor neuropathy with conduction block are 

1. Asymmetric limb weakness, especially in the upper limbs 

2. Nerve conduction studies showing focal demyelination with conduction block is a hallmark of MMN

3. Presence of anti-GM1 IgM antibodies supports the diagnosis

 

ALS has LMN and UMN findings. CMT is seen in children with stork leg appearance. AIDP is caused by Anti GM1 antibodies but has leg weakness > arm weakness and no conduction block on NCV.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about Spinal muscular atrophy?

choices.text: Risdiplam increases the production of SMN protein

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cognitive milestones are delayed

Explanation: 

Cognitive development is preserved in children with Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA), even in severe forms. SMA primarily affects anterior horn cells, leading to motor weakness, flaccid paralysis, and tongue fasciculations. Unlike cerebral palsy or metabolic disorders, SMA does not impair intellectual or cognitive function. Recurrent pneumonia and is explained by weakness of chest muscles, muscles of inspiration and poor cough effort. 

Treatment

Description

FDA-Approved Treatments

Nusinersen (Spinraza):

  • Increases SMN protein production by modifying splicing of the SMN2 gene.
  • Significant improvements in motor function for SMA types I, II, and III.
  • Other emerging therapies are under investigation.

Onasemnogene Abeparvovec (Zolgensma):

  • It is a gene therapy that delivers a functional copy of the SMN1 gene to motor neurons, enabling the production of the SMN protein.
  • It is approved for children under 2 years with SMA.
  • This treatment has been shown to enhance muscle movement, function, and overall survival.

Risdiplam 

  • It is an oral medication that increases the production of SMN protein in the body.
  • It is approved for the treatment of SMA in adults and children aged 2 months and older.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis  is experiencing significant difficulty swallowing . CXR shows evidence of bronchiectasis, Which treatment option is most appropriate for potentially extending survival?

choices.text: Monthly broad spectrum antibiotics with N-acetlycystiene

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Percutaneous Gastrostomy (PEG)

Explanation:

Riluzole – Slightly prolongs median survival in ALS by 2-3 months but does not address dysphagia or bronchiectasis due to aspiration.

Monthly antibiotics with NAC – May help recurrent infections but is supportive, not definitive or survival-extending in ALS.

PEG – Prevents aspiration by bypassing the oropharynx, improves nutrition, and is proven to extend survival in ALS with dysphagia.

Tofersen – Only for SOD1 mutation-positive ALS, which is rare (~2%). No mention of genetic testing in the question. It is latest drug for managment of ALS.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with left hand grip weakness for past one week with difficulty swallowing. On examination tongue fasiculations are present, depressed gag reflex with right leg showing spasticity with brisk knee and ankle jerks. His daughter tells that their grandfather also died due to some neurological illness. Which of the following tests will be least contributory for diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Spinal fluid analysis

 

Explanation:

The patient has combination of LMN and UMN features. Involved areas are bulbar, arm, leg. Diagnosis suspected is amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. 

Electromyography in ALS shows denervation in multiple regions and chronic reinnervation along with muscle fasicultations

5–10% of ALS is inherited (e.g., SOD1, C9orf72), especially in younger or familial cases. Less helpful in sporadic ALS, but overall genetic studies are helpful in diagnosis 

NCV will helps to  differentiate ALS from peripheral neuropathies (which show reduced sensory conduction). In ALS, motor conduction ↓, but sensory normal.

Spinal fluid analysis  is normal in ALS. It’s more useful to exclude mimics (e.g., MS, infections, inflammatory disorders).

questions.text: Which of the following signs or symptoms is not associated with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sensory loss

 

Explanation:

ALS does not involve sensory deficits; sensory function remains intact. The presence of significant sensory loss is a distinguishing feature of Subacute Combined Degeneration compared to ALS.

ALS has features of both LMN and UMN lesion  hence fasiculation, muscle wasting and hoffman sign is present. 

Hoffman sign is upper limb Babinski equivalent. It has Involuntary flexion of the thumb and/or index finger in response to flick or snap the distal phalanx of the middle or ring finger downward.

Motor neuron disease: 

Type

Characteristics

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis 

Most common; combined upper and lower motor neuron signs

Progressive Muscular Atrophy

Predominantly lower motor neuron involvement

Progressive Lateral Sclerosis

Primarily affects upper motor neurons

Progressive Bulbar Palsy

Early involvement of tongue, palate, and pharyngeal muscles (dysarthria, dysphagia)

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with progressive weakness in his limbs, accompanied by muscle wasting and dysarthria. Neurological examination reveals both upper and lower motor neuron signs. Based on the clinical features, which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis

 

Explanation:

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis is the most common type of motor neuron disease, featuring both upper and lower motor neuron signs, consistent with the patient's symptoms.

Types of Motor Neuron Disease (MND)

Type of MND

Motor Neuron Involvement

Key Symptoms

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis

Both upper and lower motor neurons

Most common form of MND.

Weakness and muscle wasting

Progressive Muscular Atrophy (Option A ruled out)

Predominantly lower motor neurons

Described as a "pure lower motor neuron" variant.

Weakness and wasting of distal limb muscles

Progressive Lateral Sclerosis (Option B ruled out)

Primarily upper motor neurons

Characterized as a "pure upper motor neuron" variant.

Spasticity, few lower motor neuron signs

Progressive Bulbar Palsy (Option D ruled out)

Early involvement of cranial nerves

Dysarthria, dysphagia

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Extraocular muscle weakness 

Explanation:

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis is a pure motor neuron disease involving both upper motor neurons and lower motor neurons. It spares sensory pathways and typically does not affect extraocular muscles. Remember the legend Stephen Hawking, sitting wheelchair-bound yet mentally alert, communicating through a computer with speech-generating software — like today’s Gemini or Siri. Bladder and bowel function are also generally preserved until the late stages.

SOD1 gene mutations lead to oxidative stress and neurotoxicity, contributing to motor neuron degeneration in ALS.
The C9orf72 gene is the leading genetic cause of familial ALS and is also commonly associated with familial Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD).
Bunina bodies, a pathological hallmark of ALS, are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions found in the anterior horn cells (LMNs) of the spinal cord and brainstem.

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is will be used to manage acute attack of NMOSD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Plasmapheresis

 

Explanation:

First answer is IV methyprednisolone. However since it is not in options, plasmapheresis is beneficial in  NMOSD and acts  by removing pathogenic antibodies from the blood, thereby reducing inflammation and preventing further damage. 

Azathioprine – Used for long-term maintenance therapy in NMOSD, not for acute attacks.

Cyclophosphamide – Also used for severe or refractory cases but not first-line in acute management.

Monoclonal antibodies – Like eculizumab, satralizumab, or inebilizumab, are used for relapse prevention, not acute treatment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female experiences bilateral vision loss and lower limb weakness. MRI of the spinal cord shows lesions spanning more than three vertebral segments. What is the most specific test for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) AQP4-IgG antibody testing

Explanation:

  • The presence of AQP4-IgG (aquaporin 4) antibodies is a highly specific biomarker for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD), distinguishing it from other demyelinating diseases like multiple sclerosis.
  • This test effectively confirms the diagnosis in patients exhibiting characteristic clinical features, such as bilateral optic neuritis and transverse myelitis. 

Investigations

Investigation

Description

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

Can show high-signal lesions, typically in periventricular areas. 

Spinal MRI: Reveals lesions over three spinal segments, distinguishing NMOSD from MS.

Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Analysis

Lumbar puncture to assess inflammation and rule out other conditions.

Pleocytosis: Increased lymphocytes may be observed.

Oligoclonal Bands: Less common in NMOSD compared to MS. (Option A ruled out)

Evoked Potentials

It measures the brain's electrical activity in response to stimuli; it is less used with MRI advancement. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with subacute onset of blurry vision in one eye and painful eye movements. She reports tingling in both legs and occasional urinary urgency over the past few months. MRI brain shows periventricular white matter lesions perpendicular to the lateral ventricles. CSF shows oligoclonal bands. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C: Multiple sclerosis 

Based on classic features of optic neuritis, sensory symptoms, urinary urgency, periventricular lesions and oligoclonal bands in CSF. Diagnosis is MS. 

NMO  has bilateral optic neuritis and longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis; associated with anti-AQP4 antibodies, no oligoclonal bands.

ADEM occurs post-viral/post-vaccination in children; causes diffuse lesions and altered sensorium  and not relapsing symptoms in adults.

Neurosarcoidosis – May mimic MS but often involves cranial nerves, meninges, and non-caseating granulomas; CSF may show elevated ACE/protein but not oligoclonal bands.

questions.text: 30-year-old is diagnosed as case of Neuromyelitis optica. Which of the following cells of brain is damaged in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Astrocytes

Explanation:

NMOSD is an autoimmune demyelinating astrocytopathy caused by AQP4 antbodies that damage the blood brain barrier via complement activation. Aquaporin-4 is a water channel protein highly expressed in astrocyte foot processes, especially around CNS blood vessels.

questions.text: 40 year old woman is diagnosed with autoimmune demyelinating astrocytopathy. Which of the following areas of brain are targetted by AQP4 antibodies seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

Explanation:

Autoimmune demyelinating astrocytopathy implies neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder due to the presence of IgG antibodies against aquaporin-4, which is a hallmark of the disease.Aquaporin-4 antibodies are primarily concentrated in several key areas of the central nervous system

  • Optic nerve → explains optic neuritis and visual loss

  • Spinal cord → associated with longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis

  • Area postrema → causes intractable hiccups, nausea, and vomiting (a classic clue)

  • Circumventricular areas (e.g., periaqueductal gray matter) → due to high expression of aquaporin-4 channels and lack of blood-brain barrier. Area postrema is circumventricular organ implying that option A and C are essentially same. 

Aspect

Details

Autoantibody

IgG antibodies against aquaporin-4 (AQP4)

Prevalence

Present in 60% to 90% of NMOSD patients

Specificity

90%

Sensitivity

70% to 90%

AQP4 function

Transmembrane water channel on astrocyte foot processes

Target Areas of anti-aquaporin-4 antibody 
  • Optic nerve
  • Spinal cord
  • Area postrema
  • Circumventricular areas (e.g. periaqueductal gray matter)

Role in NMOSD

Autoimmune demyelinating astrocytopathy

Mechanism of Action

AQP4-IgG mediates perivascular lymphocytic infiltration

Outcome

Leads to axonal loss with a preference for areas rich in AQP4

questions.text: A 38-year-old African woman presents with four months of progressive bilateral visual loss and temporal headaches. Neurological examination reveals spastic paraplegia and brisk knee jerks and ankle jerks. Work up shows Anti- aquaporin-4 antibodies. Which of the following is not seen in this condition ?

choices.text: Cloud like tumefactive lesions on MRI head

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Intracranial hypertension

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation of progressive bilateral visual loss, temporal headaches, and neurological deficits, alongside the detection of aquaporin-4 antibodies, strongly indicates NMOSD. Raised ICP is not a feature of NMOSD.
  • Lesion in hypothalamus will cause diencephalic syndrome causing severe emaciation/weight loss despite normal or increased appetite.
  • Crossed hemiplegia is due to development of lesions in brainstem. Crossed means cranial nerve palsy will be ipsilateral to lesion along with contralateral hemiplegia. 
  • MRI lesions are described below but characterstic terms asked are cloud like tumefactive lesions. 

Radiological findings in NMOSD 

Location

Characteristics

Spinal Cord
  • Longitudinally extensive lesions (≥3 vertebral segments) 
  • Central/gray matter involvement
  • T1 hypointensity in acute lesions

Brain
  • Periependymal lesions around the ventricular system 
  • Hemispheric tumefactive lesions
  • Cloud-like enhancing lesions.

questions.text: A 36-year-old caucasian woman on medical tourism visit presents with a history of recent onset left lower limb weakness, gait unsteadiness, and paresthesias. She experiences an electric shock sensation that radiates down her spine when flexing her neck. An MRI of the brain is given below. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) High-dose IV corticosteroids

 

Explanation:

  • This case is consistent with Multiple Sclerosis (Acute exacerbation)
    • Because of the patient's symptoms, including limb weakness, gait unsteadiness, paresthesias, and Lhermitte sign.
    • The MRI findings of multiple periventricular white matter lesions further support the diagnosis.
  • High-dose IV corticosteroids are the most appropriate treatment for acute exacerbations of MS, as they reduce inflammation and accelerate recovery from attacks.


 

Treatment Category

Interventions

Acute Exacerbations
  • High-dose IV corticosteroids
    • first-line treatment for acute flares (Option A)
  • Plasma exchange
    • for patients who do not respond to corticosteroids.

Disease-Modifying Therapies (Option B, C)
  • Natalizumab and Ocrelizumab are highly effective for patients who haven’t responded to other therapies.
    • Natalizumab: blocks integrin α4, preventing leukocyte adhesion to endothelial cells.
      • It has a risk of PML
    • Ocrelizumab: targets and depletes CD20-positive B cells.
  • Patients with less active disease may be started on oral medications like Dimethyl fumarate or Fingolimod (sphingosine-1-phosphate modulator)
  • β-interferon and Glatiramer have the highest safety profiles but lower effectiveness.

Symptomatic Therapy
  • Baclofen
    • used for spasticity (Option D)
  • Cholinergic
    • for urinary retention
  • Anticholinergics
    • for urinary incontinence
  • Carbamazepine, amitriptyline
    • for painful paresthesias
  • Antidepressants
  • Neurogenic bladder treatments
    • Catheterization, muscarinic antagonists, botulinum toxin injection
  • Spasticity treatments (GABA B receptor agonists)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of acute, painful vision loss in her left eye, associated with a dull ache that worsens with eye movement. She also reports episodes of leg weakness, difficulty maintaining balance, and tingling sensations in her arms. Her medical history includes recurrent episodes of blurred vision and fatigue, particularly worsening in warm conditions. What is the diagnostic test of choice for this condition?

choices.text: MRI of the brain and spinal cord

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) MRI of the brain and spinal cord

 

Explanation:

  • This is a case of Multiple Sclerosis (MS), characterized by episodes of neurological symptoms. The patient's symptoms, including acute vision loss, weakness, and sensory disturbances, are consistent with MS.
  • MRI of the brain and spinal cord is the diagnostic test of choice because it can effectively identify the characteristic lesions associated with MS, particularly in the periventricular regions and spinal cord

Test

Description

MRI
  • Imaging modality of choice for MS
  • Shows multiple asymmetric, periventricular white matter lesions (Dawson fingers)

Red arrowheads referred to as Dawson ﬁngers

 
  • Active lesions enhanced with gadolinium due to increased BBB permeability
  • Presence of plaques and black holes (T1-weighted)

Visual Evoked Potential
  • Assesses optic nerve damage (Option A)

CSF Analysis
  • ↑IgG index indicates intrathecal synthesis
  • Agarose electrophoresis: > 2 oligoclonal bands (not found in serum)

(Option D)

  • Lumbar puncture:
    • can provide supportive evidence (Option B)
    • > 5 cells/microliter; protein > 1g, cells > 75 suggests alternative diagnosis

questions.text: What additional Mcdonald criteria are required for a diagnosis of Multiple Sclerosis in patient  with 2 or more attacks and clinical evidence of 2 or more lesions?

choices.text: None, dissemination in space and in time are met
Presence of enhancing and non-enhancing lesions on MRI
New T2 or enhancing MRI lesion compared to baseline

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) None; dissemination in space and in time are met

 

Explanation:

  • In a person with 2 or more attacks and clinical evidence of 2 or more lesions, both dissemination in space (DIS) and dissemination in time (DIT) have already been established.
  • DIS is confirmed because multiple lesions exist in the central nervous system (CNS) regions
  • DIT is confirmed because multiple clinical attacks have occurred over time. Therefore, no additional criteria are necessary to make the diagnosis of MS in this scenario

 

Scenario

Requirement for diagnosis

≥ 2 Clinical attacks + Objective evidence of  ≥ 2 lesions

MS can be diagnosed – No further tests needed

≥2 attacks + 1 lesion

Dissemination in space required (MRI or new attack at different site)

1 attack + ≥ 2 lesions

Dissemination in time required (MRI or second clinical attack)

1 attack + 1 lesion

Need both DIS and DIT (Via MRI or clinical evidence)

Progressive neurological symptoms from onset (≥1 year)

Evidence of progression plus: 2 of 3

  1. DIS in brain
  2. DIS in spinal cord
  3. Positive CSF (oligoclonal bands or IgG index)

 

Abbreviations:

  • DIT = dissemination in time
  • DIS = dissemination in space
  • CNS = central nervous system
  • CSF = cerebrospinal fluid
  • T2 lesion = hyperintense lesion on T2 weighted MRI

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding One and a Half Syndrome in multiple sclerosis is not true?

choices.text: It is characterized by ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy
Limited adduction of the ipsilateral eye
The contralateral eye exhibits exotropia and abduction nystagmus.
Vertical gaze and convergence are impaired in this syndrome.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vertical gaze and convergence are impaired in this syndrome.

 

Explanation:

Vertical gaze is mediated by rostral midbrain. In one and half syndrome the lesion is in Parapontine reticular formation or abducens nerve nucleus and contralateral Medial longitudinal fasiculus 

 

 

One and a Half Syndrome

Combination of ipsilateral conjugate horizontal gaze palsy (the "one") and ipsilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) (the "half")

Physiology:

  • Visual signals from frontal and parietal lobes activate the Paramedian Pontine Reticular Formation (PPRF)
  • PPRF excites the ipsilateral abducens nucleus
  • Abducens nucleus sends:
    • Motor fibres to the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle
    • Signals to the contralateral MLF activate the medial rectus of the opposite eye via the oculomotor nucleus

Pathophysiology:

  • Possible lesion sites responsible for the horizontal gaze palsy in One and a Half Syndrome include:
    • Damage to both the ipsilateral abducens nucleus and the PPRF.
    • Damage confined to the ipsilateral abducens nucleus.
    • Damage isolated to the ipsilateral PPRF.
    • Damage to the ipsilateral abducens nerve root along with the contralateral MLF, potentially due to two separate lesions.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy. (Option A ruled out)
  • Limited adduction of the ipsilateral eye (INO). (Option B ruled out)
  • Contralateral eye: Exotropia with abduction nystagmus. (Option C ruled out)
  • Preserved vertical gaze and convergence. (Option D)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman  who is a known case of multiple sclerosis has come for follow up consultation. On examination, the left eye has slowed adduction when attempting to look to the right, and there is horizontal nystagmus in the right eye when it is abducting. Which of the following best explains the underlying pathology of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Lesion in the right sixth cranial nerve
Lesion in the left sixth cranial nerve
Lesion in the left medial longitudinal fasciculus
Lesion in the right medial longitudinal fasciculus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lesion in the left medial longitudinal fasciculus

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the history of multiple sclerosis and clinical manifestations the diagnosis is internuclear ophthalmoplegia.
  • In this case, the lesion in the left medial longitudinal fasciculus interrupts communication between the left third cranial nerve nucleus (responsible for adducting the left eye) and the right sixth cranial nerve nucleus (responsible for abducting the right eye). This results in slowed adduction of the left eye when attempting to look to the right and horizontal nystagmus in the right eye as it abducts.

Pathophysiology of INO 

  • When a person looks on the left side, the lateral rectus muscle supplied by the 6th nerve and the medial rectus muscle supplied by the 3rd nerve gets in sync with each other so that eyes can fixate on a particular object.
  • Cross-communication occurs with the help of the medial longitudinal fasciculus.
  • Lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), blocks the communication between the contralateral sixth nerve nucleus and ipsilateral third nerve nucleus, affecting horizontal gaze 

Clinical features:

  • Slowing or impaired adduction in the ipsilateral eye to the MLF lesion
  • Horizontal nystagmus in the abducting eye (contralateral eye) as a compensatory response

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a known diagnosis of multiple sclerosis visited a sauna in her gym. After the visit her vision becomes blurry and her leg weakness worsened that she had to be assisted by gym staff to her house. This presentation is called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Uthoff’s symptoms

 

Explanation:

Uthoff's symptom refers to the temporary worsening of neurological symptoms due to increased body temperature, often triggered by heat exposure, such as spending time in a sauna. This symptom is common in patients with multiple sclerosis.

Lhermitte’s symptom : An electric shock-like sensation that radiates down the back into the legs. Typically induced by flexion or other movements of the neck.

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is caused by a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), and is characterized by impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye and nystagmus of the abducting contralateral eye.
